abstract.text: In the positron-electron annihilation process, finite deviations from the standard calculation based on Fermi's golden rule are suggested in recent theoretical work. This paper describes an experimental test of the predictions of this theoretical work by searching for events with two photons from positron annihilation of energy larger than the electron rest mass (511 keV). The positrons came from a 22 Na source, tagging the third photon from the spontaneous emission of 22 Ne * de-exitation to suppress backgrounds. Using the collected sample of 1.06 × 10 7 positronelectron annihilations, triple coincidence photon events in the signal-enhanced energy regions are examined. The observed number of events in two signal regions, N SR1 obs = 0 and N SR2 obs = 0, are, within the current precision, consistent with the expected number of events, N SR1 exp = 0.86 ± 0.08(stat.) +1.85  −0.81 (syst.)  and N SR2 exp = 0.37 ± 0.05(stat.) +0.80 −0.29 (syst.) from Fermi's golden rule, respectively. Based on the P (d)  modeling, a 90% CL lower limit on the photon wave packet size is obtained.

body_text.text: Introduction

In a previous publication [1] it was shown that deviations from quantum electrodynamic (QED) calculations by Fermi's golden rule may appear in positron annihilation. Such deviations arise from the approximations made in the calculations. Explicit formulae for the expected deviations are derived fully in Ref. [1]. In this paper an attempt to detect experimentally such deviations is described. The process of positron annihilation to two photons is a simple system and their detection is suitable for a precision test of QED. A transition probability of the quantum process, P(T ), at time T is formulated by Fermi's golden rule with a certain approximation [2,3], i.e., P(T ) = T , where is the average transition rate. A problem of this approximation has been pointed out by several theoretical considerations, and it is suggested that an additive constant correction term, P (d) , is required in the formulation as in Eq. (1) [4]: P(T ) = T + P (d) .

The P (d) term has an unusual property distinct from the golden rule, and may have been buried in the background. Accordingly the P (d) term has not been seriously studied in experiments. Therefore, the golden rule was valid when the experiments were designed for its confirmation. This holds true for a slow process where T is large, but it is thought to be insufficient for rapidly changing processes . where relatively sizable effects for the correction term are expected [5]. This was shown to be the case in positron annihilation [1]. Although the processes based on the correction term, P (d) , can show a unique signature of its non-conserving nature of the kinetic energies, experimental confirmation of the effect has not been hitherto seriously pursued mainly due to its predicted broad spectrum, which would lie under the backgrounds, preventing its manifestation. In Ref. [1] it is proposed that the two-photon process of the position annihilation could manifest a sizable correction, and the feasibility of an experiment using a simple setup is discussed.A setup based on the 22 Na radioactive source surrounded by γ -ray detectors, e.g., NaI(Tl) scintillation detectors, is an ideal platform for verifying such effects. From the process, 22 Na → 22 Ne * +e + +ν, e + +(e − ) → γ 1 + γ 2 , two photons with the same energies in opposite directions are expected. Here, (e − ) are the electrons resident within the materials near the source. In Fermi's golden rule, the energies of the two photons are the electron rest mass, i.e., E γ 1 = E γ 2 = 511 keV, while, with the correction term, P (d) , it can deviate from 511 keV as illustrated in Fig. 1.

Due to the P (d) term, the intrinsic photon energy distribution would have long tails on both sides around the sharp peak at the electron mass of 511 keV. The shape of this tail depends on the size and the shape of the photon wave packets. Photon wave packet size, σ γ , is defined in Ref. [1], and 3×10 −21 m 2 is assumed in Fig. 1. Two photon packet shapes, Gaussian and power-law, are assumed, and are mixed in the typical ratio 99 (Gaussian) to 1 (power-law). In Fig. 1, these two components, together with their sum, are shown separately. The higher-energy region around 1 MeV is populated mostly by the power-law model.

In experiment, the low-energy range (E γ 1 = E γ 2 < 511 keV) suffers from a huge background produced via Compton scattering of the 511 keV photons. Conversely, the high-energy range 2/9 PTEP 2020, 043C01 R. Ushioda et al.

(E γ 1 = E γ 2 > 511 keV) is free from such backgrounds. The exception is those from double-hit pileup events discussed in Sect. 3. Events requiring two photons in opposite directions are called 2-coincidence events, and are insufficient to suppress the double-hit pileup backgrounds. However, in the process of 22 Na decays, the third photon (E γ 0 = 1274.5 keV) is emitted almost simultaneously with the positron annihilation via the de-excitation process of the 22 Ne * nucleus. Tagging of this third photon is effective in significantly suppressing the double-hit backgrounds. In this paper, the events requiring three photons, one with 1274.5 keV and the other two being detected in a back-to-back configuration in the higher-energy range, are called 3-coincidence events, and are treated as signal events.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2, the setup of the experiment is described. In Sect. 3, the models and the methodologies of the background estimation are explained. Section 4 describes the data analysis. Section 5 summarizes the results, and the results are interpreted in Sect. 6. Section 7 concludes this new measurement. Figure 2 is the top view of the experimental setup. The 22 Na radioactive source (Japan Isotope Center, 3 mm diameter aperture, 25 kBq) [6] is placed at the center, which is surrounded by six cylindrical NaI(Tl) scintillators (see later text for details), PMT1-6. As in the figure, three pairs are put in a back-to-back configuration with respect to the source, with 45 • separation between them. The scintillators face the center of the setup, and the distance between their surface and the center is 80 mm. In the center is placed a 22 Na radioactive source with the positron tagging system as shown in Fig. 3. A thin plastic scintillator plate (Saint-Gobain, φ 7.5 mm × t 0.1 mm, BC-408, polyvinyltoluene 1.023 g/cc [7]) is placed beneath the 22 Na source, then comes the small container filled with the SiO 2 powder (Nippon Aerosil, R812 (density: ∼ 60 mg/cm 3 , specific surface area: 230-290 m 2 /g) [8]). Positrons ejected from the source scintillate in the thin plate scintillator. The  scintillation light propagates through the thin light guides on both sides (CI Industry Co. Ltd [9], t 2 mm × 30 mm × 39 mm) and the second light guides (φ 38 mm × t 109.7 mm) and is then read out by two photomultipliers (Hamamatsu H6410). These PMTs are called PMTs 7 and 8, and the coincidences of these are considered as the positron signals and used as triggers. Positrons are trapped inside aerogel pores of the silica powder and annihilate into two photons. It is assumed that the positron is captured from rest [10][11][12]. This gives the magnitude of the background from in-flight annihilation as less than 10 −6 as estimated in Ref. [1]. In order to reduce the contribution from positronium formation, the silica powder container is filled with air. This positron signal timing is used to suppress the accidental background by requiring two detections, one from the combination of the γ -ray detections and one from the positron signals. Additionally, the requirement of a positron signal in the plastic scintillator can constrain the positron annihilation position to be inside the SiO 2 powder case.
Experimental setup

For the γ -ray detection, six NaI(Tl) scintillators (Ohyo Koken, 8B8 (φ 50.8 mm ×t 50.8 mm) [13]) are used. The NaI crystal is sealed in aluminum housing (4.0 mm thick in front, 2.8 mm thick on the sides). The scintillation light is read out by PMTs (Hamamatsu, H6410, H7195, H1161-50 [14]).

A CAMAC system (controller Toyo Corporation CC/NET [15]) interfaced to a PC was used for the data acquisition. The analogue signals were handled with the NIM standard modules, for the digitization, timing adjustment, and coincidence taking. As the energy deposit of positrons on the thin plastic scintillator is small, the outputs of PMTs 7 and 8 are amplified with FastAmp (Kaizuworks Corporation, 2104 [16]). They are digitized with low threshold, and timing coincidence of PMTs 7 and 8 is required to mitigate the fake signals from the noise. One output from each of PMTs 1-6 is fed into the discriminator module, and the signal timings are defined by the digitized outputs of them. A hardware coincidence of the positron signal and at least one hit out of six PMTs for the photons (PMTs 1-6), is used as a trigger for the data taking. The time difference, δt i , between the positron signal and each photon detector (i = 1-6) is measured with a time-to-digital converter (TDC, Technoland Corporation, C-TS103, 125 ps resolution [17]). Other outputs from each of PMTs 1-6 (each PMT has two anode outputs) are used to measure the energy depositions inside NaI(Tl). In order to measure the energy deposition, these outputs are subdivided into two lines, and are fed to a charge sensitive analogue-to-digital converter (ADC, Hoshin Electronics Co., Ltd, C009 [18]) with different gate widths to mitigate the pile-up events. Hereafter they are called ADC wide (gate width 1.2 μs) and ADC narrow (gate width 100 ns).
Backgrounds

Although there is no intrinsic background source for this experiment, where two photons with large energies are radiated in back-to-back directions, there are several potential sources that mimic the signal.  One such background is the environmental radiations from the walls of the experimental room. In order to reduce this, a coincidence in timing between the positron emission and the photon detections is required. The accidental coincidence rate, R acc , is expected to be in the form R acc = R e + × R γ h e + + h γ − 2h coin , where R e + is the positron detection rate (∼ 100 Hz), R γ is the environmental radiation detection rate (∼ 0.17 Hz), h e + is the pulse width of the positron signal (∼ 100 ns), h γ is the pulse width of the photon signal (∼ 100 ns), and h coin is the minimum time width required for the coincidence (∼ 10 ns). During the measured time (550 hours), five events are expected from the environmental background that concentrate in photon energies below 511 keV. Hence the environmental radiations are safely ignored.

The main background events stem from the double-hit pileup, where the data acquisition is incapable of separating two sequential 22 Na decays due to the finite time window of the coincidence module. These pileup events can be suppressed by comparisons of the two ADC measurements for the photon energies. However, this can only reduce the pileup event rate down to O(10 −4 ); therefore, a simulation-based estimation is vital. Figure 4 shows several event configurations. Figure 4(a) represents the nominal event case where 511 keV photons from annihilations are detected in opposite side detectors. Figure 4(b) is the doublehit background where two pairs of 511 keV photons are detected, i.e., 1022 keV energies in backto-back detectors. Figure 4(c) is another type of double-hit background. In this case, two 1275 keV photons from different decays are detected in the opposite detector pair by accident.

In order to estimate the double-hit background events in 2-or 3-coincidence events, a detector simulation based on the Geant4 toolkit [19][20][21] has been set up. The detector components and materials in Figs. 2 and 3 are reproduced in the simulation. In single-hit events, two 511 keV backto-back annihilation photons and a 1275 keV photon are simulated, while in double-hit events two pairs of back-to-back 511 keV photons and two 1275 keV photons are simulated. In these simulations, 1275 keV photons are emitted isotropically from the 22 Na source, and the positron annihilations are generated inside the silica powder container.

2 × 10 8 simulation events are generated in both types of events. In order to reproduce the experimental data, single-hit events and double-hit events are summed with the proper weights. The weights are estimated by using the experimental data as explained in Sect. 4.

In this experiment, the 2-coincidence detection is defined as follows: "photons are detected in at least 2 detectors and only one pair of them are in opposite directions, i.e., excluding the events with two or more opposite direction pairs." Similarly the 3-coincidence detection is defined as follows: "photons are detected in one opposite direction pair detector and in an additional detector. The energy  deposit in the additional detector, E 3 , should be 1200 keV ≤ E 3 ≤ 1390 keV. As in the 2-coincidence case, events with two or more opposite direction pairs are excluded." The requirement on E 3 strongly suppresses the backgrounds of type (c) in Fig. 4 where two 1275 keV photons accidentally hit the opposite side detectors. In these coincidence events, energy depositions in the opposite direction pair are called E 1 and E 2 , where E 1 is measured with one of PMTs 1, 2, and 3. Similarly, E 2 is the one from PMTs 4, 5, and 6. In the 2D phase space of E 1 and E 2 , three control regions (CRs) are defined. These CRs abound with background in 2-coincidence events, and they are used to normalize the distributions from simulation to the measured data. Also defined are two signal regions (SRs), where a large signal-to-background ratio is expected, and two validation regions (VRs), which are used to check the validity of the background estimation in the region close to the SRs. They are defined in Table 1. The definition of these regions can be graphically confirmed in Fig. 5. CR1 is dominated by those events in which both 511 keV photons are photoelectrically absorbed (Fig. 4(a)). The number of events in CR1, N data CR1 , is used to normalize the simulation to the observed data. CR2 corresponds 6/9

to the double-hit events in which two pairs of 511 keV photons are all photoelectrically absorbed (Fig. 4(b)). The number of events in CR2, N data CR2 , is used to estimate the amount of pileup. On the other hand, CR3 corresponds to the double-hit events in which two 1275 keV photons from different events are photoelectrically absorbed (Fig. 4(c)). The number of events in CR3, N data CR3 , is used to estimate the amount of accidental background. VRs suffer from fewer backgrounds, but they still contain a good amount of them. These are mainly from those events where one or both of the two photons in CR2 or CR3 are Compton scattered. These regions can potentially contain contamination from the signal events but are expected to be largely dominated by the background; thus it is considered to be safe to use these as VRs. SR1 and SR2 are the same as VR1 and VR2, respectively, except that they require 3-coincidence and the backgrounds are largely suppressed.
Data analysis
1.06 × 10 7 events were recorded in 550 hours, which corresponds to an average data acquisition rate of 5.4 Hz. Data were taken in 13 runs.

The energy scales of the detectors were calibrated in situ using the photoelectric absorption peaks (511 keV, 1275 keV) from the 22 Na source for each run. A linear function is used for the calibration. The TDC is a clock-counter type module, and a linearity of ±500 ps is guaranteed. Hence no calibration runs were taken for TDC.

In order to retain adequate quality of data, the following preselections are applied. Since the signal is prompt positron annihilation, the time difference between the trigger (positron annihilation) and the photon detection is constant. |δt| <1 ns around the mean timing is required. The slewing effect is confirmed to be very small for the relevant energy range ( > 200 keV), hence the slewing correction for the photon detection, i.e., energy-dependent timing correction, is not applied in this analysis.

The standard deviation of the time resolution in each photon detector is 1.2 ns and the time differences between photon detections within ±6 ns are used as coincidence events. As described in Sect. 2, for each photon detection, two ADC measurements with different gate widths are utilized to suppress the pileup events. For the signal regions (E (i) > 600 keV, i = 1-6), a cut on event E

narrow < 100 keV is applied. After the preselections, event selections for the control and validation regions are applied. Table 2 summarizes the number of remaining events after the event selection for control regions as defined in Table 1. The correction factors are extracted from this comparison, and are applied to the simulated events to compensate for the differences. Using these experimentally obtained numbers, the accidental background rate and the pileup event rate are evaluated as follows. The accidental backgrounds originate from the double-hit events and appear in CR3 where two 1275 keV photons are accidentally detected in opposite side detectors in the time window of this experiment. The accidental background event rate, i.e., the ratio of double-hit events to single-hit events, called α, is determined from the equation N data CR3 /N data CR1 = (N simul CR3,single +αN simul CR3,double )/(N simul CR1,single +αN simul CR1,double ). α is estimated to be α = (3.35 +4.43 −2.16 )×10 −4 . The estimated numbers of events in CR1, CR2, and CR3 after taking α into account are N estim CR1,α = 1.52 × 10 6 , N estim CR2,α = 1.17, and N estim CR3,α = 1.01, respectively. Since the rejection power for pileup backgrounds after the timing coincidence is weaker than for accidental background, more pileup events are expected in CR2 and in the associated lower-energy range. In order to estimate this amount, another type of simulation sample, called a semi-double event, containing two pairs of 511 keV photons and one 1275 keV photon per event, is generated, aiming to simulate the pileup events that appear in CR2 and not in CR3. The remaining number of events in CR1 and CR2 out of the 2 × 10 8 semi-double events generated, N simul CR1,semi , N simul CR2,semi , are found to be N simul CR1,semi = 2.92 × 10 6 , N simul CR2,semi = 2.85 × 10 3 . The ratio of pileup events to accidental events in CR2, β, is determined from the equation N data CR2 /N data CR1 = (N estim CR2,α + βN simul CR2,semi )/(N estim CR1,α + βN simul CR1,semi ), and is found to be β = (2.08 +2.57 −1.93 ) × 10 −3 . Based on the parameters α and β, the numbers of simulated events in various regions are normalized. The obtained values are summarized in Table 3.

The detector components are aligned, and the precision of the geometrical alignments is expected to be within ±1 mm. Systematic errors related to the following items are estimated: the distance between the photon detectors and the center of the setup, the tilt of the setup, i.e., the angular deviation of the detectors from the setup design, the actual location of the annihilations inside the powder case, etc. All of these are checked using the simulation, and confirmed to make negligible contributions to the result.
Results

VR1 is used to check the validity of the background estimations. In VR1, the number of events in the data is found to be consistently higher than the estimation (mean factor 1.56); hence a constant correction is applied on the estimation (VR1 correction) to remove this difference. The remaining bin-by-bin fluctuation is approximately 40%, which is counted as systematic error. After the VR1 correction, VR2 is used for the final validity check of the method. 46 events are observed in the data (N data VR1 ), where N estim,corre

The signal regions are unblinded after this confirmation. Figure 6 shows the observed E 2 vs. E 1 distributions of the 2-coincidence (left) and 3-coincidence (right) events. =0.37 ± 0.05(stat.) +0.80 −0.29 (syst.) background events are predicted in SR1 and SR2, respectively. With the current experimental precision, the results are consistent with the background prediction expected from Fermi's golden rule. Relatively large systematic errors stem from the propagated uncertainties of the α, β parameters, originating from the limited statistics in N data CR2 and N data CR3 .
Interpretation

In Ref. [1], the relative size of the P (d) correction term for the positron annihilation is predicted as a function of the photon wave packet size, σ γ , for power-law and Gaussian wave functions. Figure 1 of Ref. [1] illustrates the expected ratio of events from P (d) per positron in SR2. Since 0 events were observed in SR2, the 90% CL upper limit, N SR2,90CL obs , is 2.30 events [22]. The efficiencies of detecting photons in the NaI(Tl) scintillator with an 800 keV threshold, ε γ , are estimated with simulation. They gradually increase as a function of the incident photon energy, e.g., for the photon energies of 1 MeV and 1.5 MeV, they are estimated to be 28% and 38%, respectively. Conclusion

In investigating the correction term to Fermi's golden rule, an experimental test to search for positron annihilation events with two high-energy photons is carried out. Zero events are observed in two signal regions, where 0.86±0.08(stat.) +1.85 −0.81 (syst.), 0.37±0.05(stat.) +0.80 −0.29 (syst.) are expected, respectively. The result in the second signal region is interpreted with the P (d) model, yielding a 90% CL lower limit on the photon wave packet size of σ γ = 1.0 × 10 −21 m 2 . This is the first experiment to look into this correction term using positron annihilation.
